abstract: As big Web companies expand in the advertising business, can they use information provided when users set up e-mail or other accounts in ads? None do now. AOL, Yahoo, Google and Microsoft all say they could use more data in ads in the future.
snippet: As big Web companies expand in the advertising business, can they use information provided when users set up e-mail or other accounts in ads? None do now. AOL, Yahoo, Google and Microsoft all say they could use more data in ads in the future.
lead_paragraph: Just how personal can advertising from the Web giants get? That’s a question you may be wondering after reading my article in Monday’s Times and the related blog post. With big Internet companies, which already have a lot of data about users, moving into the ad network business, is every ad you see on the Internet going to reflect what you have been doing and reading about lately.

headline.main: Where Every Ad Knows Your Name

abstract: European regulators approved Google’s $3.1 billion takeover of the online advertising company, the final hurdle to a deal that would strengthen Google’s already powerful position on the Web.
snippet: European regulators approved Google’s $3.1 billion takeover of the online advertising company, the final hurdle to a deal that would strengthen Google’s already powerful position on the Web.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  European regulators on Tuesday approved Google’s $3.1 billion takeover of the online advertising company DoubleClick, the final hurdle to a deal that would strengthen Google’s already powerful position on the Web.

headline.main: Europe Approves Google’s Merger With DoubleClick

byline.original: By Stephen Castle and David Jolly

abstract: Google said it completed its $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick, a merger that rivals such as Microsoft and Yahoo had fiercely opposed. It took Google nearly a year to close the hotly debated deal: The final obstacle fell away Tuesday when European regulators approved the transaction.
lead_paragraph: Google said it completed its $3.1 billion takeover of DoubleClick, a merger that rivals such as Microsoft and Yahoo had fiercely opposed. It took Google nearly a year to close the hotly debated deal: The final obstacle fell away Tuesday when European regulators approved the transaction.
